titlestmt.subtitle: Papers of Karl Jay Shapiro and Theodore Roethke, 1940-1962, at the Lilly Library, Indiana University
titlestmt.author: Mary McSparran

change.item: Edits and rearrangement of content to create sections for abstract, bioghist, controlaccess, scopecontent, acquisitioninfo, related materials, and levels for container list were applied. Madison Chartier
Batch update to change subject links.

did.abstract: The Shapiro mss., 1940-1962, consists of the writings of poet Karl Jay Shapiro, 1913-2000, and his correspondence with poet Theodore Roethke, 1908-1963.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Many collections are housed offsite; retrieval requires advance notice. Please make an appointment a minimum of one week in advance of your visit.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Photography and digitization may be restricted for some collections. Copyright restrictions may apply. Before publishing, researchers are responsible for securing permission from all applicable rights holders, then filling out the Permission to Publish form.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Karl Jay Shapiro, 1913-2000, was a poet and essayist selected to be Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress.
Theodore Roethke, 1908-1963, was a professor and poet known for his use of rhythm and imagery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Shapiro mss., 1940-1962, consists of the writings of poet Karl Jay Shapiro, 1913-2000, and his correspondence with poet Theodore Roethke, 1908-1963. At this time, Shapiro was editor of the Prairie Schooner at the University of Nebraska and Roethke was teaching at the University of Washington.
The writings are comprised of drafts of poems, some with revisions in the poet's hand, worksheets, alternate versions, and a notebook of worksheets labeled "No Goodniks."

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Shapiro mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana.
